chapter: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a cause for deviated nasal septum?
questions.explanation:
Allergic rhinitis does not cause deviated nasal septum (DNS). Etiology of DNS: • Trauma - during passage through the birth canal or trauma after birth leading to fracture of the 
nasal septum • Developmental error - may be associated with cleft lip, cleft palate • Racial factor - more common in Caucasians • Hereditary - affects more than one member of the same family
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 2: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the 
following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Clinical features of DNS: • Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation • Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the 
nose • Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses • Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa • Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction • Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on roomier side • Frequent middle ear infections 375 
Sold by @itachibot • Association with external deformities
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 3: What clinical test is depicted in the image? 369 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the 
patient breathes quietly. This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. 
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of 
the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side. Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV. Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. 
Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four 
abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some 
airway. 376 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient 
is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose 
firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 4: An ENT surgeon is performing septoplasty in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Which of 
the following is not an indication for the surgery?
questions.explanation:
Nasal discharge is not an indication for surgery in a patient with deviated nasal septum (DNS). Indications for surgery in DNS: • Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches • Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur 377 
Sold by @itachibot • Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndrome Other indications for SMR (submucous resection) and septoplasty: • As a part of septorhinoplasty for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidian 
neurectomy (transseptal approach) • For the approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviated 
septum obstructs the view and access to these areas • To gain access for endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient diagnosed with deviated nasal septum is undergoing submucous resection. What is 
the key incision is used in this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Killian’s incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2–3 
mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum. Option B: Shobinger incision is used in modified radical neck dissection. Option C: Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incision 
taken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella. Option D: Weber Ferguson incision is used in maxillectomy.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 6: A 20-year-old college student presented with complaints of facial pain, nasal discharge, 
headache, and nasal bleeding. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis in the past. On anterior 
rhinoscopy examination, the nasal septum is deviated. Which of the following is the 
treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is a case of deviated nasal septum and septoplasty is the treatment of 
choice. Both submucous resection and septoplasty can be done for DNS. Septoplasty is a conservative 
approach and more commonly done nowadays. Septoplasty is also the preferred surgery for DNS 378

questions.question:
Question 8: A mother brought her 5-year-old child with complaints of pain and swelling in the nose and 
difficulty in breathing after an alleged history of fall while playing. On examination, there is 
bilateral swelling of the nasal septum which is tender and erythematous. Which of the 
following is false about the given condition?

options.b: Can result in hump nose deformity
options.d: Accumulation of blood under the perichondrium

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with bilateral septal swelling following trauma is suggestive of a septal 
hematoma and can result in saddle nose deformity, not hump nose deformity. Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal 
septum. It is caused due to trauma, septal surgery, and bleeding disorders. Clinical features 
include pain, swelling, and bilateral nasal obstruction (the most common presenting feature), and 379 
Sold by @itachibot sometimes, frontal headache. Complications include septal abscess, depression of dorsum (saddle nose), and permanently 
thickened septum.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 9: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in 
breathing. Which of the following is the best management for this child?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with swelling in the nose after trauma is suggestive of septal hematoma 
and it needs immediate surgical drainage. Treatment of septal hematoma: • Aspiration of small hematomas • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.explanation:
Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation. Causes of septal perforation: • Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, 
foreign bodies • Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays • Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, 
rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis • Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma • Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large 
perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts. Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. 
In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and 
bland ointments.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 11: A middle-aged man with tertiary syphilis presented with complaints of epistaxis, nasal 
crusting, and nasal twang on speaking. On examination, nasal septal perforation was noted. 
What is the most likely site for the perforation?

options.d: Junction of the bony and cartilaginous septum

questions.explanation:
The given patient is having nasal septal perforation due to syphilis. The most common site of 
involvement in syphilis is the bony nasal septum. Other chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can cause 
perforation in the cartilaginous part. Wegener’s granulomatosis causes perforation of both bony 
and cartilaginous parts. 380 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 12: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presented with foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal 
crusts, and epistaxis. She was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. On examination, maggots 
were seen in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is used in the treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Myiasis (maggots in the nasal cavity) is a complication of atrophic rhinitis. It is treated with 
chloroform diluted with water. The maggots are larval forms of flies especially genus Chrysomia. The flies are attracted by the 
foul-smelling nasal discharge in conditions like atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, and lay eggs in 
the nasal cavity. These eggs hatch into larvae within 24 hrs and cause intense irritation, 
lacrimation, sneezing, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Treatment: • All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps • Instillation of chloroform water and oil kills them • Nasal douche with warm saline is used to remove slough, crusts, and dead maggots.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question: Question 13: Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of nasal polyp formation. Bernoulli’s principle states that when the velocity of air increases, the lateral pressure will 
decrease. When air passes through the nasal valve area which is the narrowest region of the nasal 
cavity, velocity increases. This creates a negative pressure that sucks mucosa of sinuses into the 
nasal cavity leading to polyp formation.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 14: 372 
Sold by @itachibot A 45-year-old man was prescribed aspirin for post-MI prophylaxis. But whenever he takes the 
medication, he develops difficulty in breathing, sneezing, and lacrimation. He has a known 
family history of bronchial asthma. Which of the following is related to the his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Samter’s triad where the patient will have aspirin intolerance, 
asthma, and ethmoidal polyps. Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp: • Chronic rhinosinusitis especially non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome • Allergic fungal sinusitis • Asthma • Cystic fibrosis • Kartagener syndrome - This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary 
dyskinesis • Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia • Churg–Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma 381 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not part of Kartagener’s syndrome?
questions.explanation: Azoospermia is not a component of Kartagener's syndrome. Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of: • Bronchiectasis • Sinusitis • Situs inversus Kartagener syndrome is one of the etiology for ethmoidal polyps.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question: Question 16: What is Young’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Young's syndrome consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia. Option A: Neutrophilia with red papular rash is seen in Sweet’s syndrome/acute febrile 
neutrophilic dermatosis. Option C: Mitral stenosis with ASD forms part of Lutembacher syndrome. Option D: Nasal polyp, asthma, aspirin hypersensitivity form Samter’s triad.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 17: A 40-year-old woman came to OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction, headache, 
sneezing and nasal discharge. On examination, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are 
present bilaterally that don't bleed on touch. Which of the following is false about the 
diagnosis?

options.b: The site of origin is lateral wall of the nose
options.c: FESS is the treatment of choice
options.d: The mass can grow posteriorly and occupy the choana

questions.explanation:
The given case scenario with multiple bilateral nasal masses in a middle-aged woman is suggestive 
of ethmoidal polyp and it doesn’t grow posteriorly to occupy choana.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 18: You are an intern examining a child who presented with nasal obstruction and discharge. On 
anterior rhinoscopy, there is a single smooth glistening mass in the right nasal cavity which 
can be moved up and down with a probe and doesn’t bleed on touch. The mass is extending 
posteriorly and occupying the choana. Which of the following is false regarding this 
condition?

options.a: Infection and allergy are the main etiological factors
options.b: The site of origin is maxillary antrum
options.c: FESS is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with findings of a single, unilateral polyp that extends posteriorly to 
occupy the choana in a child is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp. It can present with hyponasal 
voice and not hypernasal voice.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis

questions.question:
Question 19: A middle-aged man with recurrent diffuse ethmoidal polyps is scheduled for a laser-assisted 
FESS procedure. Which of the following lasers is ideal in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
KTP laser (potassium titanyl phosphate) is the ideal laser for the treatment of nasal polyps. Option A: Nd-YAG laser due to its greater depth of penetration has a higher risk of complications 
within the nasal cavity. Option C: CO2 lasers are primarily used for laryngeal interventions. Its use in nasal sinus surgery 
is restricted as it causes extensive scarring and it cannot be delivered through a flexible 
fiber-optical system. 382 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: The use of argon lasers is limited in sinus surgery due to the high cost of the laser tube 
and the need for a high current power supply and water flow for cooling. 383 
Sold by @itachibot Trauma of Nose and Face
